This report presents 3 key findings from an analysis of Nutrition_Physical_Activity_and_Obesity. The analysis addressed 12 questions focused on exploring patterns, relationships, and insights within the data.

![](plot_1768932400002_0_0.svg)

This choropleth map displays adult obesity rates across the continental United States in 2023, with states colored on a gradient from green (lower rates) through yellow to red (higher rates). A clear regional pattern emerges, with southeastern and midwestern states showing the highest obesity prevalence (exceeding 35%), while western states like Colorado demonstrate notably lower rates, highlighting significant geographic disparities in obesity across the nation.

![](plot_1768932400002_1_0.svg)

This radar chart compares five key health indicators between Colorado and West Virginia in 2023, revealing stark differences in health outcomes. West Virginia (shown in red) consistently exhibits worse outcomes across all metrics—including obesity, overweight prevalence, physical inactivity, and low fruit and vegetable consumption—while Colorado (shown in green) demonstrates a notably smaller footprint, indicating healthier population behaviors overall.

![](plot_1768932400002_2_0.svg)

This grouped bar chart provides a direct comparison of health metrics between Colorado and West Virginia, with percentage point differences annotated above each pair. West Virginia exceeds Colorado by substantial margins across all indicators, with the largest gaps appearing in obesity (+15.9 percentage points) and physical inactivity (+12.7 percentage points), underscoring the significant public health challenges facing West Virginia relative to one of the nation's healthiest states.
